display: Can you build a simple Claude MD for this Repository. It is essentially a repository to keep some CSS files in another application up-to-date. All it does is pull from a origin repository just a particular set of files. If changes are present these files are pulled.Also in the Claude MD can you provide quick links to all the containing folders?
great. Let's talk about the CSS system. I've noticed that the framework uses changes to the variables in a style attribute to customise styling. What can you say about this?
So it is also component based. But utility styles are called last on the HTML Application layout. Does this indicate that they may also be overrides? Or just useful for non-component items?

the docs/technical/snippets folder is full of official examples of how to use this framework. what can you tell me about it? the badge file shows style overides, the prose files seems to have manipulated the tag directly. chack a few others and see what you can gather.

hmm i wouldn't say that style overides are more common. it seems as though they have a different purpose than utilities. almost like measures and sizes (that you don't want to create a 1000 diferent utility classes for) where as utilities are for things that need consistency and positioning.
great. So my Claude.md is a little outdated and our discoveries here can be incorporated. ive left some `%% claude instructions %%` inside the file as a guide
one more change to the best practices
I was hoping you might write that a bit more sucinctly than me (the dislexic) can
look at this file what to you think it means?
Im having trouble with dependabot making new branches in my repo. I want to firstly "clear" them. then secondly prevent them from showing up constantly
lets chat a bit first, what is happening here with these branches? they seem to have gem updates on each one?
how easy it to merge them? can't we just use bundle update to have this natively update?
shit we don't branches deleted do we I have some permanent branches. I think i will look at option 1
no you asked me to approve this `--delete-branch-on-merge=true` bash command
i just deleted dependabot.yml on main

We have a few commits to make. staged files contain updates pulled from upstream css files, and the addition of a large amount of component snippets. we have a "clients" generator i still want to do more work on, so don't commit it yet. Also is there any other changes ive made outside of these that i have forgotten?

ok so routes is in clients work. application.html.erb is part of css refactoring and updating. the stylesheets claude file is part of the css work. docs clients is part of client building. looks like i was also refactoring the feature recording flow (this could be a separate commit. actually lets work one by one, suggest all css refactoring files, then suggest in a numbered list any other files that could possibly have been involved in css refactoring and i will give you the numbers to inlude.
1 & 2. claude.md is an app build workflow refactor.

umm...

The next bunch of staged files are a refactoring of documentation surrounding code scratchpads, and a renamed folder that was involved, wich cascaded down into some file paths.
stop adding to the staged files doofus. I litterally had the commit setup for you with the staged files and the explanation behind the changes.
so ive staged all the ui component snippets and supporting files. lets commit those
I have a staged file that should've been commited with the scratchpad refactor commit. can this be added now?
try again ive rebased the scratchpad commit to be the last commit. th eammend should work now

So this is a claude code custom command. I want you to duplicate it with the following changes. 
- rename to commit-staged.
- refactor so that claude uses only staged files for a single commit. 
- removes all the requirments to look for atomic commits and splitting

keep user arguments but change it so that the user can describe the changes that they made. If these arguments are present then claude can use the argument as a naming guide (in conjunction with his git diff)

Thank you that is great. can we also look at this agent instructions file, I am looking to convert from a general css helper to one that specifically knows about the css approach. and can serve up exactly what the main agent will find usefull. can we discuss this?

I have been updating my css approach instructions. I have a method  whereby we keep the core framework files clean and any customisations go into separate but same named files (this allows us to update the core files without destroying our custom additions). can we discuss if you think this claude.md files highlights this enough?
yes, but maybe we should mention to also search both the base stylesheet and the custom stylesheet when looking for classes to style with?

great addition. now i was thinking that the folder / files references that begin around line 70 and finish around 160 are at the same (H2) level as all these additions. Im feeling they should be appropriately nested under a h2 heading something like `## Framework Overview`, would do you think of this proposed change?
made the changes myself, just want to check if you like tham?
ahh so you mean we talk about customising, then we talk about arcitecture overview, then we talk about external snippets, then we talk about the arcitecture again?
nahh i did it, thank you pointing it out tho, i think it reads much better also
Can you put your expert css architect hat and review the system. Can you see any improvements and gaps?

hangon "usage guidlines" IS the descision matrix. it would be redundant to have both of these sections. i think we should merge your detailed descriptions into the existing matrix. do you have any other ideas?
yep add when to use. keep existing erb examples. change utilities to second in the list. best practices change 3. to say how to refernece tokens (in variables/), instead of three examples.
lets discuss this section in our claude.md. it is a convoluted workflow description. do you have any improvement or cleanup suggestions?

I like the first one although that has been sumarised. i really want to flesh it out so it is a rock solid process. some additions...
- we create and maintain a feature build checklist in docs folder
- describe backend enhancement then use those as examples
- frontend enhancement with components first THEN further hotwireing
how would you describe the Validations, Callbacks, Scopes, Error Handling etc in models and controllers?
i want to describe them as a whole, they seem to police the code making sure it doesn't error or fail. could you call it the defensive code?

to be honest they all constrain the model. They have a similarity to an "overhead" in business. the model does all the great and wonderful things then it has to be constrained so it behaves. these things are a cost when coding, just to ensure proper behaviour. like the business analogy.

Your task is to complete this xml file continuing the current pattern. Basically we are mirroring the files in `docs/technical/snippets` some files contain various versions of the snippet this is also being reflected.

chart, combobox, command, drop down, drop zone, flash, group, layouts, popover, prose, resizable, scroll area, sheet, sortable, tabs, toggle & trix, all have multiple files. I don't think you read the files into context to see them, can you update these?

So these are placeholders for creating views using a special xml scratchpad for each view. build a view by placing the necessary place holders in a "tree". Use single line closure for elements with no children, elements with nested children use open and close tags. This system is for fast iteration, adding or moving the pieces around can happen easily without cost. Also we can see where elements are "coming from" either as custom components or semantic tags etc. what is your take on this?
yep you said it well. can you help me to fill in any more <HTML_elements> or <erb_tags> we may use commonly. Also are the plain text explanations clear or could we improve those?

I was more looking to explain with this line that the builder should add their own attributes to the xml to explain configuration of the HTML tag/component. The key here is that we don't need to mirror HTML attributes, as per the scratchpad idiom. things like "path=post.show" on a <link_to> tag can reveal our intention with clarity and ease.

Is what a i have written to describe this concept good enough for somebody who doesn't exactly know?
Looks like you have a good understanding of what we are doing with these placeholders can you help me adjust claude.md "scratchpads" section so that html scratchpad methodology is also incorporated.

just a reminder, the current version that was written with modeling in mind doesn't use examples. that is because we have a specific reference sheet (ruby_scratchpads.md) that shows comprehensive examples. can you update with using examples or metaphors, like the original version.

can you review this file. it is an output style for claude code to follow when working on rails fronent architechture. we are looking to follow the latest conventions in rails whereby server side rendering of standard web is used.
they are intentionally avoid i have a custom personal framework that becomes more apparent as workflows are revealed through claude.md files. this is just an introduction

now this one. the key focus here is to start simple as most modern rails apps start as MVP's and then bocome more enterprisey after they can effectively work. However claude is trained on enterprise rails codebases and likes to go straight for the complox code.

Im looking at installing tailwind 4 in this project. We have done some minimal styling work so far (login flow and clients). Can you look over the codebase and give me some direction on the effort required to introduce (and ultimately replace) tailwind for our styling needs. Also any feedback on gotcha's or secondary refactoring would be welcome (eg planning system).
Lets discuss first and then we might write a plan to introduce tailwind.

Ok so you've given the case against essentially, let me give the case for...
- TW 4 is now css based, no preprocessors, no tailwind.config.js. css files can easily be imported. 
- claude really struggles with this framework, he just writes utilities anyway, and most time uses TW utilities that don't exist.
- TW4 comes with comprehensive token system.
- TW4 has some very good prebuilt component libraries. (tailwind plus, https://railsblocks.com/)
- This css-zero looks ugly.
- can do away with complex guardrails. I prebuild with copy paste component libraries directly in erb. You help hook up the logic.
- You help me style a few pages just how we want, then i extract the utility classes to our very own componenets. then we re-use for consistency, instead of the styling drift seen with ai and TW3.

I also think I will keep our snippet library and stimulus controller archived but nearby, there are some unique components i have seen in this one, that i may need to convert over into TW, its just the ergonomics of css-zero is too much. I want option A, but i want you to write it into a plan (tailwind_integration.md) in root folder. use an informative but concise style, with minimal examples (they bloat the plans too much).

ok so I have made some progress. experimenting with phase 2. I have imported some button component / partials from rails blocks (`docs/rails_blocks/imported/buttons/`). can we look to extract them to buttons.css in our `/assets/tailwind/components/` directory?

lets do cards, `app/assets/tailwind/components/cards.css` is already created. cards are here `docs/rails_blocks/imported/cards`. can we extract the styles, remember TW can utilise css nesting and all most other modern css patterns

`& h3,
 & .card-body-title`

Convert these components into reusable semantic CSS classes in `app/assets/tailwind/components/$ARGUMENTS.css`

Preferrably extract the classes directly using the `@apply` directive, If needed vanilla CSS can be added to the classes for customisations better suited to direct CSS.

I just updated the /github:issue-start slash command to fix how it handles the --comments flag.
  Previously, when using --comments, it would only show comments and hide the issue body. Now it
  should run two separate commands to get both.

  Can you test both modes:
  1. /github:issue-start 22 - should fetch body + metadata only
  2. /github:issue-start 22 --comments - should fetch body + metadata AND comments (via two separate
  gh commands)

I'm in the process of finishing off a workflow out lined in gh issue 18. I think this might be a better use case for bundling as a skill (at least a large part of it). we can bundle the issue templates, pr template, labels usage. command stages. this way i could keep the output-style focused on the actual style and slash commands minimal and understandable. what is your thoughts?

I actually think it would be better to split it all up into branches and have no "workflow" understanding, instead a "toolset". eg sandbox.md issue-kickoff.md issue-improve.md, issue-formatting.md (messages vs body), pr-formatting.md etc. this would allow me to just "do' the workflow and you can use any tool branch appropriately as it arises.
look at issue 18, Can you review if there are opurtunities here to turn this into a skill?

nah lets talk more. for me we shouldn't squeese workflows into skills. skills give us a unit of related tools that all work in combination to give an ability. in this particular situation I see a github-cli skill and a sandbox skill. these tell us how to work with tools so we can do something (workflow). 
github-cli tools...  bash commands, labels, issue (quick, improve, plan, start, close), PRs (drafts, closing), templates, formatting (message vs body), conventions.
sandbox tools... format, location, convention, gitignored, cleanup.
our slash commands can then change to be more descriptive and expressive, rather than being mainly "how to use gh cli for this command"
then I can simply do a workflow without having to say imdoing a workflow

so looking at composability i think we actually have three skills. One is gh-cli, the other is github flow, then the last sandbox. we also have some others in codebase... scratchpads, feature documentation. we even have rails building (models with namespaced concerns), hotwiring (the frontend) and progressive enhancment. if we can think of "the xxxxxx skill" (skill here is the literal term) then we have something we can competently do with our codebase.

1. think github-flow uses gh-cli and sandbox, you simply reference these in the SKILL.md file. What would "use github" mean for CC if he was in a codebase that didn't use GHF. he would need to know about commands, formats, templates, labels, how to find comments etc. 
2. yeah you can nest skills under larger ones, a house builder can "lay foundations", as well as "construct roof" to "build house".
3. no these are context reducers. all skills are listed very minimally (just metadata) in the system prompt anyway, then SKILL.md loads for whatever skill claude uses,  then this file directs to templates, code runners, other files.

it also cleans up alot of other CC tools and commands. claude.md can now be purely to memorise certain quirks of the codebase, output-styles set tone and style, slash commands natural language repeatable prompts. i estimate being able to clean up about 60-80% of tokens these tools currently use and transfer them over to skills. nearly almost all of the non chat tools went into setting context.

In issues 18 and 27 we have had 2 attempts at solidifying a workflow using gh-cli, github flow, and a specialized sandbox.
 issue 18 used an output style as the core structure supported by slash commands and claude.md
issue 27 refactored to base the workflow off the new skill feature added to claude, with minimal use of any other CC tool. 
18 caused problems with claude having to "manage" the whole process. 27 caused problems because skills are janky claude calls them only when he thinks the situation calls for it.

ok this command is how to pre-load an issue with comments `!gh issue view $ARGUMENTS && echo -e "\n========== COMMENTS ==========\n" && gh issue view $ARGUMENTS --comments` as there is a quirk with `gh issue view --comments` only loading comments and not the main issue. 
alot of your preloading instructions are mis formatted "`!`gh blah blah``" it should be `!gh blah blah`"
